content: Fixed some missing/wrong formatting in Input, Output and Constraints sections.
Added "loop N write answer" to stub generator.
You probably mean '1900 was no leap year while 2000 was one'.

The invalidity reasons are not given in a logical order (1 does not make sense if 2 and 3 are not already valid) and item 4 contains typos: "DDMMYYYY" (4 'Y'), "2000 was no leap year while 1900 was one" (that's the contrary).

The statement is long for what it is and the puzzle is not very original:
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/credit-card-verifier-luhns-algorithm

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun, tests are working, description is clear, interesting =)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Actually a very nice contribution, phenomenal job.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting easy puzzle. Allow us to learn or see again how to verify a date format and some string manipulations. A question : how should Austria do if there is more than 999 births in one day ? I think it's impossible now because they have an average of 230 births for a day but in the future ?

Thank you, mate.

Well, good question. I guess they will extend it like ISBN-10 -> ISBN-13 but I am quite sure that this will take ages. Austria has currently 9 mio inhabitants.

By the way, according the algorithm there are by far no 999 births per day.
The very first digit must not be 0 (reduces to 899) and due to the "modulo 11 = 10" calculation further 81 numbers are skipped (approximately).

So only 818 births per day can be assigned.

From friends which moved to Austria from abroad I know that they receive some social number as well.

But it seems not to be an urgent issue.

The 1900 and 2000 is annoying. You are fully right! When applying the rules for a leap year this error becomes obvious.
Strange that after reading the text so often, I missed this point.

Thank you for the feedback about the order of invalidity reasons. It was my first classic puzzle and indeed, it makes sense to list the reasons in the order you've proposed.
Ouch! You and Niako are fully right.
You can still edit the puzzle after approval.
Thanks for the answer slogslog ! Hope your puzzle will be accepted ;-)
